Award.AwardTitle: Longitudinal Evaluation of Noyce Science Teachers to Determine Sources of Effective Teaching

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
There is a well-documented need for competent, confident, and committed science teachers to serve in high-need school districts. This Phase 2 Noyce project will produce thirty new certified secondary science teachers. It will leverage the work of the Phase 1 Noyce project, and continue the collaboration between the University of Nebraska-Lincoln and the Lincoln Public Schools, to address the overarching question: What aspects of teacher recruitment and preparation lead to effective teaching by beginning and intermediate science teachers? In addition, the project will conduct a research study to compare two different routes to teacher certification, a traditional four-year undergraduate program that meets the state's minimum certification requirements and an extended Master of Arts program (developed through the Phase 1 Noyce grant) that exceeds state requirements and meets the national definition of "highly-qualified" for science teachers.

By advancing the field's knowledge of how individual aspects of teaching interact with one another and the long-term effect of science teacher education on effective secondary science teaching, researchers and teacher educators can better understand how to recruit teacher candidates and create more informed science teaching education programs, thus contributing to the education of more highly qualified science teachers. The project's objectives are to: (1) Analyze potential differences between two routes to science teacher certification using pre-post systematic data collected on pre-service teachers (specifically: demographic information, subject matter knowledge, clinical experiences, emergent pedagogical knowledge and instructional practices, and teaching beliefs and self-efficacy); (2) Analyze two programs' long-term interactions with science teachers' beliefs, self-efficacy, instructional practices, and overall effectiveness (specifically: student learning, teacher retention, and dropout rates); (3) Test two models of teacher preparation that connect attributes of teacher preparation and effective science teaching; and (4) Disseminate key findings on science teacher preparation and teacher effectiveness to teacher educators and science education leaders and associations. Multiple and mixed methods will be used for the longitudinal study and evaluation of the project activities. This work, funded by the National Science Foundation's Division of Undergraduate Education's Robert Noyce Teacher Scholarship Program, will provide reliable information for state and national policy makers related to teacher preparation and certification, thus empowering teachers to nurture generations composed of intelligent citizen consumers of scientific knowledge and practices and, potentially, encourage more people to choose STEM-related careers.

POR.DRECONTENT:
NSF Noyce Track I, Phase II grant (2015-2020) at the University of Nebraska-Lincoln (UNL), Department of Teaching, Learning, and Teacher Education (Dr. Elizabeth Lewis, PI)

There were two major foci of the UNL Noyce grant, the 30 Noyce stipends to recruit science majors to become science teachers (broader impact) in a master's level teacher preparation program and the ancillary research in the form of a longitudinal study (intellectual merit). 

Broader impact. We successfully recruited 31 preservice science teachers and are on track for 29 of them to be certified as highly qualified teachers by June 2021. The school partnerships that were built across not only this grant, but its predecessor also resulted in strengthening these ties. Specifically, several of the mentor teachers from our NSF Noyce Track I, Phase I Noyce Scholars provided placements for this grants' Noyce Scholars during their student teaching semester. This interaction between past and current preservice Noyce teachers has strengthened the Nebraska science teacher community as a direct result of NSF funding.  In Cohorts 7-9, to date 24 of the 25 certified teachers obtained a teaching position within 2 years, of whom 95.8% (n=23) are still teaching. By individual cohort, teacher retention rates range from 71.3% to 100% for each of the nine cohorts of teachers who have completed UNL's masters-level Noyce-supported teacher education program (MAT) since 2012; Cohort 10 will complete the teacher preparation program for state certification in June 2021.

Intellectual merit. One of the major differences that we have been able to control for in our study of beginning science teachers is their level of science content knowledge.  Per NSF requirements, teachers from the UNL MAT program have at least an undergraduate degree in an area of science, whereas the undergraduate preservice teachers (not supported by Noyce stipends) have only slightly more than a minor degree in their (in-field) science area with at least another 12 credit hours in ancillary science courses. Research findings from the project support a clear priority for more rigorous science teacher preparation in science content knowledge, teaching methods, and educational foundations to produce high levels of teaching self-efficacy in beginning science teachers. Specifically, having membership in a high-quality teacher preparation program that requires an undergraduate degree in science, coupled with ongoing teacher professional development once teachers begin to teach, is important for continued long-term growth in inquiry-based classroom instruction the longer that teachers had completed their teacher preparation programs. In our analysis the teachers' program membership (in favor of the MAT program) also correlated with better curricular choices, higher levels of teaching self-efficacy, and use of rich discourse and assessment. A greater use of inquiry-based instruction aligns with the current vision of modern science teaching. Thus, if state policymakers only require a general science program for secondary science teachers that does not concurrently require robust in-field expertise (i.e., 30 or more college-level credit hours in one area), states risk undermining such science education reform efforts. Research findings from this NSF Noyce grant-funded project have been shared with local, national, and international science education teacher educators, researchers, and educational policy audiences to encourage practical changes in how science teachers are prepared and inform how states set their certification policies.

In terms of professional development within the university setting, for four of the five years of the UNL Noyce project, the NSF grant funding supported four graduate research assistants (doctoral students in science education), at half time (10 hours per week). The PI has been their major academic advisor, mentoring these individuals as future faculty, educational researchers, and scholars in the field of science education. These former and current UNL doctoral students have been taught research skills, critical thinking habits, and co-authored conference presentations and publications while working in as a part of the research group. The PI worked with the research team to: (1) obtain human subjects research approval through university and school district institutional review boards; (2) collect a range of different types of data and maintain reliable data records; (3) conduct data analyses; (4) propose and draft accepted conference presentations (posters and papers); and (5) draft and submit manuscripts for publication. Additionally, two of these four doctoral students successfully completed and defended their own dissertations in 2017 and 2019. These studies were designed in conjunction with the main Noyce-funded study, but additionally encouraged students' own design and respectively focused on beginning science teachers' use of metacognition strategies and technology in science lessons. Two other doctoral students are in the early and late stages of their dissertations (on track to finish in 2021 and 2022) focusing on teachers' use of Next Generation Science Standards (the U.S. national K-12 science education standards) science and engineering practices.
